posts.name: tsinghal0504
posts.cooked:
no suitable constructor exists to convert from “int” to “units::unit_t<units::time::second, double, units::linear_scale>”

Any suggestions? I have about 15 of these errors.

posts.name: Sylvain D.
posts.cooked:
What function is giving that error?

Probably a function prototype changed. Check the Java API documentation.

posts.name: tsinghal0504
posts.cooked:
We’re using C++ and the following function:

frc::Counter::SetMaxPeriod(int) Wait(0.002)

It seems there is something wrong with the Counter and Timer Class; however, I can’t pinpoint it

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Did you read the changelog ? There were a ton of changes for this year, so more support for the Units API would not surprise me at all.

link_counts.title: New for 2022 — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Sylvain D.
posts.cooked: Many C++ methods migrated to using “units” instead of int/double. I’d look into that. Maybe your parameter need to have another type or be explicitly casted into the unit.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: You will have to learn to use the C++ units library .

link_counts.title: The C++ Units Library — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: As Oblarg pointed out, Timer switched to using units in C++.  To make your line of code work, it needs to be Wait(0.002_s) (or Wait(2_ms) ) rather than Wait(0.002)

posts.name: tsinghal0504
posts.cooked: Awesome, thank you! Fixed the Issue instantly!

posts.name: system
posts.cooked: This topic was automatically closed 365 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
